questions.text: What is the innermost layer of the sclera?
questions.solution:
Lamina fusca is the innermost layer of the sclera.

Lamina fusca faces the choroid. It is the transition zone between the sclera and the choroid. It consists of a delicate meshwork of elastic fibres, fibrocytes and melanocytes, traversed by long posterior ciliary nerves and vessels.

Layers of the sclera from outside to inside include episclera, sclera proper, and lamina fusca, in that order.

questions.text: The sclera is the thinnest at which of the following locations?

choices.text: Anterior to attachment of the superior rectus
Posterior to attachment of the superior rectus

questions.solution:
The sclera is the thinnest posterior to the insertion of the rectus muscles.

The sclera is 1mm thick posteriorly, with maximum thickness around the optic nerve, 0.66 mm at the insertions of the rectus muscles and 0.33 mm beneath the rectus muscles and thinnest behind their insertions

questions.text: A patient sustained a severe blow to the right eye from the lateral side during a fistfight. The eyeball is soft to touch and a rupture of the sclera is suspected. What is the least likely site of rupture?
questions.solution:
The lateral limbus is the least likely site to be involved in a traumatic scleral rupture.

Traumatic scleral rupture, or globe rupture, occurs after blunt-force trauma. It usually occurs due to the compression force of the trauma. It therefore likely occurs at the insertion of rectus muscles, at the equator, or in an area parallel to the limbus opposite from the site of the impact. Rupture at the site of trauma, in this case lateral limbus, is rare. 

The major signs of scleral rupture are conjunctival edema and subconjunctival hemorrhage, hyphema, ocular hypotony, impairment or dislocation of the lens, vitreous hemorrhage, and retinal detachment.

questions.text: What is the predominant type of collagen in the sclera?
questions.solution:
Collagen type I is the predominant type of collagen found in the sclera.

Collagen forms 50 to 75% of the dry weight of the sclera. Type II is absent in the sclera. It is found in the vitreous body of the eye.

questions.text: A patient with glaucoma presents with a bulging cornea. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
High intraocular pressure leads to the thinning of the outer tunics of the eyeball such as cornea and sclera, thereby resulting in their ectasia (bulging) which is known as staphyloma. Ciliary and equatorial staphylomas are most commonly associated with glaucoma.

Staphyloma is an abnormal protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weak and thin portion of the cornea or sclera. So, staphyloma is lined internally by uveal tissue and externally by weak cornea or sclera.

Types of Staphyloma:

Types  Pathology  Causes

Intercalary staphyloma Due to bulging of weakened limbal tissue at the limbus, internally lined by the root of iris & the anterior most part of the ciliary body

Developmental glaucoma 

Secondary angle closure glaucoma

Healing of perforating injury

Ciliary staphyloma  Due to bulging of the weakened sclera, internally lined by the ciliary body, can extend up to 8mm behind the limbus

Scleritis

Scleritis

Posterior staphyloma Due to bulging of sclera lined by the choroid, seen behind the equator 

Posterior scleritis

Pathological myopia

Keratoconus (Option A) is a progressive bilateral corneal ectatic disorder due to defective synthesis of mucopolysaccharide and collagen tissue. It usually starts at puberty and progresses slowly, not associated with risk factors like glaucoma. Therefore, we can rule out keratoconus in this patient.

Staphyloma (a bunch of grapes) is a clinical condition characterized by ectasia (dilation or bulging) of the outer coats (cornea or sclera or both) of the eye with the incarceration (trapping) of the uveal tissue.

questions.text: The ciliary staphyloma is due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ciliary staphyloma is due to scleritis.

Ciliary staphyloma is the ectasia (bulging) of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body. This affects the ciliary zone that includes the region up to 8 mm behind the limbus. It can be caused by scleritis, absolute glaucoma or trauma to the ciliary region of the eye.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complaining of irritation in her left eye has the following finding. Which of the following condition commonly causes this?
questions.solution:
Irritation in the eye associated with areas of scleral thinning through which the uvea shines is suggestive of scleromalacia perforans. It is commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

Scleromalacia perforans is a specific type of progressive scleral thinning without inflammation. Despite the term 'scleromalacia perforans', perforation is extremely rare as the integrity of the sclera is maintained by a thin layer of fibrous tissue.

Other collagen disorders associated with it are as follows:

  • Wegener’s granulomatosis (option B)
  • Polyarteritis nodosa (option A)
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Relapsing polychondritis

questions.text: The most common type of scleritis is ______.
questions.solution:
Non-necrotizing anterior scleritis is the most common type of scleritis. 

Scleritis can be classified into anterior and posterior scleritis. Anterior scleritis affects the sclera in front of the equator, while posterior scleritis affects the sclera behind the equator of the eye. Anterior scleritis is further classified into the following types:

  1. Non-necrotizing
    1. Diffuse: The most common variety
    2. Nodular: Scleral nodules are present. Annular scleritis is a variant in which the scleral nodules are arranged in a ring around the limbus. 
  2. Necrotizing
    1. With inflammation
    2. Without inflammation: Also known as scleromalacia perforans. It is seen in elderly females with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis.

The image below shows anterior nodular scleritis.

questions.text: All the following statements are true for a 40-year-old diagnosed with scleritis except-

choices.text: Scleromalacia perforans is associated with systemic disease.
Pain is not a prominent feature.
Retinal detachment is a known complication.

questions.solution:
Pain is a prominent feature of scleritis.

Scleritis is an inflammation of the sclera. Patients present with moderate to severe eye pain, redness, lacrimation and photophobia. Anterior scleritis affects the sclera in front of the equator and may lead to the following complications: 

  • Acute infiltrative stromal keratitis
  • Sclerosing keratitis
  • Peripheral ulcerative keratitis
  • Uveitis
  • Glaucoma
  • Hypotony (rarely phthisis)
  • Perforation of the sclera

Posterior scleritis involves the sclera behind the equator and may lead to uveal effusion with choroidal detachment, disc edema, proptosis or exudative retinal detachment.

Scleromalacia perforans is a type of anterior scleritis. It typically occurs in elderly women with rheumatoid arthritis (systemic disease). There is ischemia and necrosis of the sclera; however, there is no inflammation. Clinically, it is a painless condition with a white eye. Areas of thinned out sclera through which the uvea shines are seen in such patients.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presented with a two-week history of gradually worsening sharp and stabbing left eye pain with redness. The severe pain kept her awakened during the night. On investigation, B-scan ultrasound shows the 'T' sign due to fluid accumulation in sub-tenon space. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of severe worsening eye pain with redness and a B-scan showing T sign due to fluid accumulation in sub-tenon space is suggestive of posterior scleritis.

Posterior scleritis is the inflammation involving the sclera behind the equator. Ultrasonography in posterior scleritis may show the following:

  • Increased scleral thickness
  • Scleral nodules
  • Separation of tenon capsule from the sclera
  • Disc oedema
  • Choroidal folds
  • Retinal detachment
  • Fluid in the sub-tenon space may give a characteristic "T" sign. The stem of the "T" is formed by the optic nerve and the cross-bar by the fluid-containing gap. 

The image given below shows a B-scan ocular ultrasound of the eye.

questions.text: A patient develops  surgically induced necrotising scleritis following an ocular surgery. The patient most likely underwent any of the following surgeries except:
questions.solution:
Surgically induced necrotizing scleritis (SINS) may occur following any ocular surgery involving the creation of a scleral wound. Tarso-frontalis sling surgery is a lid surgery and does not involve the sclera.

SINS is a condition of scleral inflammation and necrosis that may occur as a complication of the following surgeries:

  • Pterygium excision
  • Cataract surgery (especially with sclero-corneal tunnel)
  • Trabeculectomy
  • Vitreo-retinal surgeries
  • Squint surgery

SINS is more likely to develop in those with rheumatoid arthritis, connective tissue disorders or following intra-operative use of mitomycin C. It is treated with NSAIDS and systemic steroids.

questions.text: As a first-year ophthalmology resident, you come across a child with the following presentation. Which of the following disorders is it associated with?
questions.solution:
The child has blue sclera which is associated with osteogenesis imperfecta. 

Blue scleral discoloration is due to scleral thinning. The underlying uvea thus becomes prominent and visible. Osteogenesis imperfecta (types I and IIA) and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (type VI) are the most commonly associated diseases. Both diseases are inherited disorders of collagen formation. 

Other options:

Option A: Hemochromatosis occurs due to iron deposition in various tissues. Rusty-brown perilimbal conjunctiva and scleral discoloration are seen.

Option C: Congenital ocular melanocytosis occurs due to an increase in the number, size and pigmentation of melanocytes. Sclera is multifocal slate-grey pigmented.

Option D: Rheumatoid arthritis may present with extraarticular manifestations such as secondary Sjögren’s syndrome where keratoconjunctivitis sicca can be seen.

questions.text: The sclera is thick in all the following conditions except-
questions.solution:
The sclera is not thick in buphthalmos.

The sclera is 1mm thick posteriorly, 0.66mm thick at the insertion of recti and 0.33mm thick beneath the recti. In buphthalmos, the sclera is stretched and thinned out, resulting in “blue sclera.” Buphthalmos refers to an enlarged eyeball due to congenital glaucoma.

questions.text: An intern comes across a 7-year-old girl with the following features. All the following are components of her condition except-
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a young girl with facial asymmetry, deviation of angle of the mouth, flat nasal bridge, preauricular tags and limbal dermoid (lenticular yellow tumour at the limbus) of the eye is suggestive of Goldenhar syndrome. Lung hypoplasia is not a component of this syndrome. 

Goldenhar syndrome or oculoauriculovertebral spectrum is a congenital developmental anamoly affecting structures derived from the first branchial arch. It has the following features: 

  • Systemic:
    • Hypoplasia of the malar, maxillary, and mandibular regions
    • Macrostomia and microtia
    • Preauricular and facial skin tags
    • Hemivertebrae (usually cervical)
    • Mental handicap
    • Cardiac, renal, and central nervous system (CNS) anomalies.
  • Ocular:
    • Dermoid
    • Upper lid notching or coloboma
    • Microphthalmos
    • Disc coloboma
